sub_topic: Schwarz reflection principle and its applications
message_1: Let $f(z) = \frac{1}{z-i}$ be an analytic function in the upper half plane $\mathbb{H}$. Use the Schwarz reflection principle to extend $f(z)$ to the lower half plane and calculate the value of $f(-2)$.
message_2:
To extend $f(z)$ to the lower half plane using the Schwarz reflection principle, we first need to find an analytic function $g(z)$ that is equal to $f(z)$ on the real axis and is also analytic in the lower half plane. 

We can define $g(z) = \frac{1}{z+i}$, which is analytic in the lower half plane. Now, we need to find a function that is equal to $f(z)$ on the real axis and equal to $g(z)$ in the lower half plane. 

We can define the function $h(z)$ as follows:

$$h(z) = \begin{cases}
f(z) = \frac{1}{z-i}, & \text{if } \Im(z) \geq 0 \\
g(z) = \frac{1}{z+i}, & \text{if } \Im(z) < 0
\end{cases}$$

Now, we can verify that $h(z)$ is equal to $f(z)$ on the real axis:

$$h(z) = \frac{1}{z-i} = \frac{1}{z+i}$$

$$\Rightarrow (z-i)(z+i) = (z+i)(z-i)$$

$$\Rightarrow z^2 - i^2 = z^2 - i^2$$

This equality holds for all $z$ on the real axis, so $h(z)$ is indeed equal to $f(z)$ on the real axis and equal to $g(z)$ in the lower half plane.

Now, we can calculate the value of $h(z)$ at $z = -2$:

$$h(-2) = \frac{1}{-2+i}$$

Since $-2$ is in the lower half plane, we use the definition of $g(z)$:

$$h(-2) = \frac{1}{-2+i} = \frac{1}{-2+i} \cdot \frac{-2-i}{-2-i} = \frac{-2-i}{(-2)^2 + i^2} = \frac{-2-i}{4+1} = \frac{-2-i}{5}$$

So, $f(-2) = h(-2) = \frac{-2-i}{5}$.
